definition:
in advance : ahead                                      
             
             marching on before

at an earlier time                                      
             
             the night before

forward of : in front of                                      
             
             stood before the fire

in the presence of                                      
             
             speaking before the conference

under the jurisdiction or consideration of                                      
             
             the case before the court

at the disposal of                                      
             
             the great sums placed before him

in store for                                      
             
             got the whole summer before you

preceding in time : earlier than                                      
             
             just before noon

in a higher or more important position than                                      
             
             put quantity before quality

earlier than the time that                                      
             
             call me before you go

sooner or quicker than                                      
             
             I'll be done before you know it

so that … do not                                      
             
             get out of there before you get dirty

until the time that                                      
             
             miles to go before I sleep

or else … not                                      
             
             must be convicted before he can be removed from office

or else                                      
             
             get out of here before I call a cop

rather or sooner than                                      
             
             would starve before he'd steal
at an earlier time
to or toward the place where someone is going : in advance
at a time preceding (something or someone) : earlier than (something or someone)
—used to describe a time earlier than a specified hour
preceding (something or someone) in order or in a series
earlier than the time that : earlier than when
until the time that
—used to refer to something that might happen

at an earlier time                                      
             
             I've been here before.

ahead                                      
             
             go on before

in front of                                      
             
             He stood before a mirror.

earlier than                                      
             
             You got there before me.

before in order                                      
             
             Your name is listed before mine.

in the presence of                                      
             
             She spoke before a crowd.

ahead of the time when                                      
             
             Wash before you eat.

sooner or quicker than                                      
             
             I'll be done before you know it.

more willingly than                                      
             
             I'd starve before I'd steal.

until the time that                                      
             
             It wasn't long before he caught on.

in the presence of                                      
             
             then personally appeared before me

to be judged or acted on by                                      
             
             a case before the court

We arrived shortly before six o'clock.
He left just before sunrise.
I've never seen her so happy before now.
Call me before your arrival.
She arrived the day before yesterday.
Why haven't you ever helped me before now?
Your name is listed before mine.
You'll see my house just before the bank and after the school.
The Great Plains stretched endlessly before them.
The championship fight took place before a crowd of thousands.
He left long before morning came.
Say goodbye before you go.
Call me before you arrive.
I finished the exam before he did.
It was not long before he arrived.
I've been here before.
go on before

You got there before me.

Wash before you eat.
I'll be done before you know it.
I'd starve before I'd steal.

then personally appeared before me
a case before the court
a bill coming up before Congress

definition: earlier than a particular time, event, or action
at a time in the past
used for saying how much time passes until something happens
used for saying that something happens which prevents someone from doing what they intended
used for warning someone that something bad may happen unless they do something
used for saying that something or someone is judged or considered by a group of people
used for saying that something is happening where people can watch it
if one place is before another place on your journey, you come to it first
in front of someone or something
used for saying that something is placed earlier than something else in a list or series
used when saying what will happen in someone’s future
in: I went for a run before breakfast.
The others had got there before us.
Won’t you have another drink before you go?
I joined the police in 1999. Before that I was in the army.
Two weeks before the election the first reports of the scandal began to appear.
before doing something: You should seek legal advice before signing anything.
Haven’t we met before somewhere?
Never before in modern history has one nation dominated the world so completely.
Several years went by before I realized that David had lied to me.
Before I could think of a reply she walked away.
Clean up that mess before your father sees it.
You’d better go away before I lose my temper.
The case went before a grand jury on December 17th.
The question before us is whether we should allow a foreign government to control our commerce.
The team scored an impressive victory before 76,000 fans at Arrowhead Stadium.
A few miles before the border we were stopped at an army checkpoint.
Our house is just before you get to the end of the road.
Lawrence knelt before the king.
Before the temple gate stood a bronze statue of Buddha.
The names are in alphabetical order, so ‘Barnes’ should come before ‘Brown’.
A promising career stretched out before him.
You’re still young – you have your whole life before you.
the day/week/weekend etc before
the day before yesterday/the week before last etc

definition: at or during a time earlier than (the thing mentioned):
until (the event mentioned):
in the past:
in front of:
If a place is before another place, you will arrive at it first when you are travelling towards the second place:
If something is before someone or before a group of people, it will be formally considered or examined by that person or group:
Before last means before the most recent:
in: You should always wash your hands before meals.
Before leaving he said goodbye to each of them.
She's always up before dawn.
Before he could reach the door, she quickly closed it.
Before we make a decision, does anyone want to say anything else?
She had to give the doorman a tip before he would help her with her suitcases (= he would not do it until she had given him a tip).
It was an hour before the police arrived.
He said he had never seen her before.
I feel as though I've been here before.
The letter K comes before L in the English alphabet.
Many mothers put their children's needs before their own.
We have the whole weekend before us - what do you want to do?
He stood up before a whole roomful of people, and asked her to marry him.
The bus stop is just before the school.
The proposal before the committee is that we try and reduce our spending by ten percent.
The men appeared before the judge yesterday.
I left early because I wanted to arrive home before dark.
Before making up your mind, think about all your options.
It was another half hour before (= until) the ambulance finally arrived.
Less than a week before, he’d graduated from college.
Today is Monday, so the day before last was Saturday.
It took courage to stand before a courtroom full of people.
Homelessness has reached a record level, topping last year's and the year before's, of 37,519 families.
We might take some other trades, but we should soon get into difficulties because we should be speaking without all the facts:before us.
They make decisions based on their understanding of the law and the facts before them.
Beginning with the introduction of the secret ballot in 1958, the rural population had become more politically active than ever before.
In one patient intramedullary ependymoma was accidentally diagnosed during standard exams before surgical correction of scoliosis.
Therefore, social programs must promote work, and even enforce it, assuming the function that the workplace did before.
The value of this book, however, is to tease out the various 'micro-foundations' of divergent employer preferences, and to evaluate them more systematically than before.
Also, before resistance starts to appear in human isolates of fluke.
Indeed, we have seen in the previous subsection that setoids and morphisms of setoids must come before and be the base of category theory.
Rats were prohibited food and water for 12 h before infection.
A research bias favouring certain helminth groups over others has been suspected before.
The problem needs to be addressed before the situation becomes as serious as it is with other, more broadspectrum anthelmintics.
Political fund regulation should be legislated before other political reform.
Further research is clearly needed on the processes of party list construction before we have an answer to this question.
Controls were asked about food and restaurant exposures for the week before the matched patient's illness, using the same questionnaire format as for cases.

translated_as@fr: Ma famille et mes amis passent avant mon travail.
Elle fait passer sa carrière avant tout le reste.
Ils ont saisi le tribunal de l’affaire.
Le groupe se produit devant de larges publics.
se tenant debout devant les portes de l’église
Beaucoup de temps s’est écoulé avant que nous le revoyions.
Vous feriez mieux de partir avant qu’il ne se fâche.
en moins de temps qu’il ne faut pour le dire
Elle sera devenue adulte en moins de temps qu’il ne faut pour le dire.

definition: something that is prior to something not after

Marginalized Orientations, Gender identities, And Intersex. it’s meant to be an all inclusive umbrella term for asexuals, homosexuals, multisexuals, trans people, and intersex people. Alternative to LGBTQIAP+
Alternative to MOGII, easier to pronounce.
The word before can also mean in front of, ahead of. It is an old meaning which is rarely used nowadays.

before  (BEE four) noun.  in this instance, before refers to when  families, or individuals, went by their last names -- generally in the Old Country prior to emigrating to the USA.  so as not to be identified with any particular ethnic, religious, nationality, etc. the last name was changed to appear more 'American' in order to 'fit in.'
a food item that is taken before the main course of a meal.
A mathematical term for addition. (slang)
